problem: Find the largest value of $c$ such that $\frac{c^2 + 6c -27}{c-3} +2c = 23$.
solution: Factoring the quadratic gives $\frac{(c-3)(c+9)}{c-3} +2c= 23$.  Canceling the common factor gives $c+9 + 2c = 23$.  Solving this equation gives $c = \boxed{\frac{14}{3}}$.
chatgpt_solution: First we note that $c\neq 3$ because of the denominator. Since we have an expression with $c-3$ in the denominator, we can invoke Simon's Favorite Factoring Trick: add and subtract $9$ in the numerator to get \[\frac{c^2 + 6c -27}{c-3} +2c =\frac{c^2 + 6c -27+9-9}{c-3} +2c=\frac{c^2 + 6c -18}{c-3} +(2c-6)\] Factoring the numerator in the fraction, we get \[\frac{(c-3)(c+9)}{c-3} +(2c-6)=c+9+2c-6=3c+3\] Thus we have $3c+3=23$, so $3c=20$ and $c = \boxed{\frac{20}{3}}$. We can check that this solution works by inserting $\frac{20}{3}$ back into the equation; alternatively, since we used $c\neq 3$ in our first manipulation, $c=3$ would not be a valid solution anyway.
